Paper: [Causally estimating the effect of YouTube's recommender system using counterfactual bots](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2308.10398.pdf)
Why should we care: One of the first studies to estimate the effects of the YouTube recommender system on radicalisation using counterfactual viewing series, using bots.
It introduces E-BERT, which aligns Wikipedia2Vec entity vectors with BERT's wordpiece vector space, enabling the use of entity vectors as if they were wordpiece vectors.
The paper introduces a marginalization technique to performance inference at prediction time for a trained marked temporal point process when presented with mark censoring.

Paper: [Causality Guided Disentanglement for Cross-Platform Hate Speech Detection](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2308.02080.pdf)
Why should we care: The paper introduces a hate speech detection model that uses a VAE to extract causal embeddings separated into platform independent features useful for predicting presence of hate, and platform dependent features useful for predicting the target of hate.

Paper: No reading due to public holiday
Adaptable Transfer Learning Models for Online Misinformation Detection
[Demystifying embedding spaces using large language models](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.04475)
Why should we care: This paper introduces a novel framework to interpret and interact embedding vectors by leveraging the power of LLMs.

Paper: [Unmasking the Web of Deceit: Uncovering Coordinated Activity to Expose Information Operations on Twitter](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.09884)
Why should we care: This paper delves into the detection of key players driving IOs by employing similarity graphs constructed from behavioral pattern data.
